Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The O-Buoy Network of Chemical Sensors in the Arctic Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration: Collaborators from five institutions will work to build and deploy an Arctic Ocean network of rugged and autonomous buoys (named ?O-Buoys?) capable of observing atmospheric O3, BrO, and CO2 and oceanic pCO2 for a period of up to 5 years (with each O-Buoy being operational for up to 2 years). The original O-Buoy project funded by NSF included design and testing of the O-Buoy. In the current project, 11 new O-Buoys will be constructed and deployed along with the four already built. As a pilot project, two of the new O-Buoys will include seawater sensors for CO2, oxygen, temperature and salinity in addition to the atmospheric O3, BrO, and CO2 sensors. Throughout the project, data from each O-Buoy will be subject to QA/QC protocols by automated processing initially, with preliminary data available on a regular basis on the Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (CADIS) site. All final data and metadata will be ultimately archived on CADIS after final analysis at the end of each deployment. This network of O-Buoys, coordinated and clustered with other buoys in automated drifting stations, will enable the scientific community to first observe and, next, better understand the impact of Arctic surface change on atmospheric composition and chemistry. Outreach to local K-8 schools will include an ?Adopt-a-Buoy? program. Video footage from deployments/recoveries and interviews with colleagues and native Arctic people will be contributed to the ongoing http://www.arcticstories.net site, and activities and results will be communicated via the O-Buoy web site.

Project Outcomes Report for: Collaborative Research: The O-Buoy Network of Chemical Sensors in the Arctic Ocean (2010–2016)


In this project, fifteen autonomous measurement platforms, which are known as O-Buoys, were designed, constructed, and deployed onto sea ice floating on the Arctic Ocean.  These O-Buoys measure three sentinel atmospheric chemicals, ozone, carbon dioxide, and bromine monoxide (BrO) and report the data via satellite communications to the investigators' research laboratories.  These data were processed and have been made available for community use at the ArcticData.io data center.  The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) group is responsible for bromine monoxide measurements and has finalized more than 400,000 individual measurements that were further analyzed into nearly 9,000 hourly average ground-level BrO measurements spanning six years.  Each group involved in the project reported other atmospheric chemical measurements from the O-Buoy measurements, and all data are available at the NSF Arctic Data Center:

http://arcticdata.io/

Intellectual Merits: These data are ground-truth observations of atmospheric chemicals that can be used to test chemical / transport models that describe the Arctic atmosphere.  The data from this project represents the first year-round measurements of these atmospheric chemicals and first long-term data set measured over Arctic sea ice.  Initial observations showed that both the amount and vertical distribution of bromine monoxide was highly variable and coupled to atmospheric temperature structure.  Long term observations were correlated with sea ice properties.  However, the main goal of this project was publication of the data for community use, which will enable future scientific advances.

Broader Impacts: Our group has carried out extensive public outreach as well as publishing multiple peer-reviewed journal articles describing the measurements and development of analysis methods (citations below). Three UAF graduate students who worked on this project completed advanced degrees (one Ph.D. and two M.S. degrees) and are now enabled to pursue advanced careers in science.
